```auth: {
        algorithm: "rs-256",
        authority: "${SPLICE_APP_UI_AUTH_URL}",
        client_id: "${SPLICE_APP_UI_AUTH_CLIENT_ID}",
        token_audience: "${SPLICE_APP_UI_AUTH_AUDIENCE}",
        token_scope: "daml_ledger_api"
      },```

    export IMAGE_TAG

text:
No worries. For  the full context.
Bottom line is  until the wallet and cns UI  is updated to send the correct scope in the request we had to make these changes to make it work. That will raise another issue however if you are not already discouraged :sweat_smile:. The audience that will be set  in the JWT token will be the one of the default Windows Azure Active Directory entreprise application.  The scope you send determine the audience the token is issued. So until we can set this properly we have to make some compromises.
We were waiting for this issue to be resolved before you published the guide for anybody that want to use EntraID otherwise it kind of messy.

Specifically, should we comment out the migrating: true line again for future redeployments that are not related to a Canton network migration (e.g., regular maintenance or configuration updates)?

root.text: I have a question about the 3.3 upgrade and the @daml/ledger library - the interface to the library is high enough level that the change in <https://docs.digitalasset.com/build/3.3/reference/lapi-migration-guide?_gl=1*124i7x3*_gcl_au*NzAyNTk2NjQ4LjE3NDE3MTIwOTQ.*_ga*ODE4NDA5MTYuMTcyMzI0MTc5Nw..*_ga_GVK9ZHZSMR*czE3NDgzNzEyMjkkbzQyJGcwJHQxNzQ4MzcxMjI5JGo2MCRsMCRoMCRkX0I0RmhtLV9NdW1mdEV3bVBEemxTamI3TWNSbkZLSFN5Zw..&_ga=2.168527266.2027810370.1748371230-81840916.1723241797#application-id-to-user-id-rename|https://docs.digitalasset.com/build/3.3/reference/lapi-migration-guide?_gl=1*124i7x3*_g[…]&_ga=2.168527266.2027810370.1748371230-81840916.1723241797> doesn't seem to impact our inputs, but it's not clear if the change would impact the @daml/ledger implementation (and thus we'd need to upgrade @daml/ledger to the version for 3.3) or if the change is encapsulated by the JSON API and handled in the layer that converts the JSON API requests to the underlying grpc requests.

ah that explained it. when using compose you re-deploy and bring up the container with and make sure to have `-m` and `-M` <https://docs.dev.sync.global/validator_operator/validator_major_upgrades.html#deploying-the-validator-app-and-participant-docker-compose>

it's explain there

```Restart the validator, while updating the migration ID in the -m <migration ID> argument, and also including -M to instruct the validator to perform the actual migration to the new migration ID. Note that -M is required only in the first startup after the migration, to instruct the validator to perform the actual migration. Followup restarts should keep the -m <migration ID>, but omit the -M.```
